questions.text: The sebaceous gland synthesizes and releases the sebum, protecting the skin from external factors and dehydration. It is responsible for the suppleness of hair and skin. The microscopic exocrine gland is an example of ?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Type Exocrine gland
Secretion Sebum 
Secretion Process Holocrine secretion (cell disintegration)
Function - Lubricates and waterproofs skin and hair
  - Protects skin from external factors
  - Helps prevent dehydration of skin
  - Maintains suppleness of hair and skin
Location Found throughout the body, except for palms/soles
Associated Structures Hair follicles
Control Influenced by hormones (androgens)
Common Disorders Acne, sebaceous cysts, seborrheic dermatitis

questions.text: 11-year-old girl with fever, sore throat, and bilateral swellings between palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal folds, which lymph nodes should be evaluated to assess the initial spread of infection from the affected lymphoid tissue?
questions.explanation:

Deep Lymph Nodes

  • Submandibular
  • Preotic/pre auricular
  • Parotid
  • Postotic
  • Occipital
  • Retropharyngeal
  • Jugulodigastric
  • Jugulo omohyoid

questions.text: A 6-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. He feeds 10 to 12 times a day. He was born at 38 weeks gestation and weighed 1800 g. He currently weighs 1700 g. His mother has Graves’ disease and received propylthiouracil during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), his pulse is 180/min, and his respirations are 50/min. Examination shows mild diaphoresis and a firm 2-cm midline neck swelling. The actively secreting follicles of the structure involved in the patient's pathology are lined by one of the following?

As a first-year resident in the Orthopaedics department, you observe a 15-year-old male presenting with frequent fractures every 3 months. Suspecting osteogenesis imperfecta type I, which type of collagen is involved in this disorder?
questions.explanation:

questions.explanation:

questions.text: An image of the shoulder joint region is given in the figure. Identify the type of epiphyses A, B, and C respectively:

questions.text: A bulge known as the Torus aorticus is present superior to the coronary sinus and anterior to the fossa ovalis on the interatrial septum. Which of the following structures is the most likely reason for the bulge?

options.label: B
options.text: Aortic sinus bulging into the left atrium

options.label: C
options.text: Aortic sinus bulging into the right atrium

questions.correct_answer: C. Aortic sinus bulging into the right atrium

questions.text: Which of the following are the two muscles between which the Rotter’s nodes lie ?
questions.correct_answer: C. Pectoralis major and pectoralis minor

questions.text: The scapula's inferior angle lies at the level of ?

A 4-year-old boy brought to OPD by his parents. He has had foul-smelling watery diarrhoea for the last 5 months. His weight and height are below the 50th percentile . To estimate total body fat, a subscapular skin fold thickness is needed. What is the name of this device is used for this purpose ?

A preterm jaundiced newborn is born to a mother with a history of diabetes and hypertension . The mother also gave an account of jaundice in her second trimester. She also has a previous record of jaundice during both last pregnancies. A baby has a disorder of bile transport that led mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In which of the following is this seen?

A final year student is presenting a case of a 15-months old child who, upon examination, has a mongoloid slant of eyes, epicanthic fold, and simian crease . Her growth is retarded, with no dentition; there is also history of delayed dentition in one of the siblings . At what age is the dentition considered to be delayed?

Marie is a cute little girl. Her mother spends the entire day with her and teaches her new words, she tries to do whatever her mother asks her to do, and speaks the words that her mother asks her to say. With her increasing age, she can grasp more words. What would her vocabulary be on her second birthday ?

A child presents with his stepmother in the outpatient department with complaints of fever and continuous irritability . She does not know his exact age. On examination, the baby was in a tripod position, had a bi-dextrous approach, had stranger anxiety, and could speak monosyllables. Based on the above findings, what is the estimated age of the baby ?

A 1-week-old preterm male infant with low birth weight presents in the emergency department with the complaint of high-grade fever, seizures, poor feeding and irritability . His mother had a history of prolonged labour (> 18 hours) and poor socioeconomic status. On general physical examination, he is tachypneic and has a bulging anterior fontanelle and delayed capillary refill pressure . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 39-year-old primigravida pregnant woman presented to an obstetric emergency and delivered a baby at 30 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1000 grams. On a general physical examination, the baby was bradycardic and hypotensive. The baby was searched for an IV line as the baby requires fluid administration due to hypovolemic shock caused by perinatal blood loss. What would be the 24-hour fluid requirement on day 1 for this preterm baby?

What is the likely cause of illness in a 14-month-old boy born to an HIV positive mother who presents with symptoms of fever, vomiting, profuse watery diarrhea, moderate dehydration, and deep-set eyes, along with examination findings of normal body temperature, elevated heart rate, and low blood pressure?

A 59-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit after surgery following a motor vehicle collision . She has received a total of four units of packed red blood cells . Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and flat neck veins . Serum studies show a creatinine of 2.1 mg/dL , and urine microscopy shows granular, muddy-brown casts . A renal biopsy specimen is obtained and examined under light microscopy. Which of the following irreversible cellular changes is most likely to be present?
questions.correct_answer: C. Vacuolization of the endoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been admitted to the surgical emergency for resectioning pheochromocytoma. During the ward round, the attending surgeon asks the junior residents about the metastatic potential of the pheochromocytoma. Which of the following is the most reliable feature of malignant transformation of pheochromocytoma?

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of metastasis to other organs

questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of metastasis to other organs
questions.explanation:
Clinical features of pheochromocytoma.  
Epidemiology Adults; both sexes; all ages, especially 30-50 years
Biologic behavior 90%  benign; 10% malignant
Secretion High levels of catecholamines; most secrete norepinephrine
Clinical presentation Episodic or sustained hypertension, sweating, palpitations, hyperglycemia, glycosuria
Macroscopic features Mass, often hemorrhagic; 10% bilateral; 10% extra-adrenal
Microscopic features Nests of large cells, vascular stroma

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after right-sided weakness and impaired speech onset. On admission, she is diagnosed with thrombotic stroke and treatment with alteplase is begun. Neurologic examination four weeks later shows residual right hemiparesis. A head CT scan shows hypoattenuation in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery. Pyogenic infection and brain infarction are associated with which type of necrosis?

A medical student is learning about bradykinin. Bradykinin is a peptide that promotes inflammation in response to infection. It causes arterioles dilation by releasing nitric oxide, prostaglandins, and hyperpolarizing factors. The synthesis and metabolism of bradykinin are shown in the image below. The role of bradykinin in the process of inflammation is:

questions.text: A college laboratory experiment is done to evaluate the chemotactic potential of a group of potential mediators in inflammation . He learned that the leukocytes roll for several seconds over endothelial cells before arresting. The electron microscopy image below depicts the rolling of leukocytes on endothelial cells ; identify the protein involved in this process.

A 37-year-old man develops a significant respiratory stridor within minutes following a bee sting with dyspnea and wheezing . An epinephrine injection helps reverse these event s completely, and then he recovers within a few minutes. Which of the following chemical mediator is not involved in the pathogenesis of this man's condition?

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of smoking and hypertension presents to an outdoor urology clinic with complaints of severe lower back pain associated with anorexia and unintentional weight loss of 15kg in six months. He denies associated urinary urgency, frequency, hesitancy, dysuria, or nocturia. Digital rectal examination reveals a firm, hard, asymmetrical, and stony prostate with a rough nodular surface, suggestive of prostate malignancy. A transrectal biopsy of prostatic tissue is taken and sent for histopathological analysis. Which of the following tumour markers is not useful in the immunohistochemistry analysis of prostatic carcinoma?

A 23-years-old patient presented to the outpatient department with complaints of change in colour of stools to black, fatigue, and weakness. He also experiences shortness of breath and occasionally chest pain. He has a present history of peptic ulcer disease and gastritis. On laboratory investigation, his faecal blood test turned out to be positive . He is referred to a gastroenterology clinic. He is taking large amounts of unidentified drugs that inhibit platelet activity . Which of the following product helps to promote platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction in the metabolic pathway of the arachidonic acid (AA') metabolism?

A 5-year-old child has been brought to the clinic with easy bruising and fatigue for the past few weeks. On examination, no abnormal findings are noted. Bone marrow study has revealed the myeloblasts and promonocytes in the bone marrow of more than 20%. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which genetic mutation is present in the given condition?

A 20-year-old military trainee is brought to the emergency department due to a high-grade fever for 2 days . It is associated with nausea, vomiting and headache . His medical history is positive for viral meningitis at the age of 6 years . His previous records show that he lacks membrane attack complex (MAC) . Physical examination shows neck rigidity . Laboratory investigations reveal TLC 15x10 9 cells/L with a neutrophil count of 7x10 9 cells/L . Which of the following is the most likely cause of infection in this patient?

A 39-year-old female known case of chronic liver disease presented to the emergency department with complaints of generalized body weakness, malaise, and easy fatigability for one month. On examination, she was pale-looking; the digital rectal examination was performed, which was insignificant. Her complete blood count showed microcytic anaemia with Hb 6.8 g/dL. An iron profile was also ordered. Which among the following is the best parameter for the assessment of body iron stores?

A 22-year-old female presents to the gynaecology department with complaints of recurrent abortions over the last two years. She is further evaluated, and it is revealed that chromosomal abnormalities caused the recurrent abortions. A study shows that when a chromosome splits along an axis, the axis is perpendicular to the conventional division axis. What is formed when a chromosome is applied along an axis?

A 26-year-old African-American pilot working in the military develops fatigue, weakness and lethargy a week after redeploying to a new area. On examination, he has pallor, jaundice and splenomegaly. His investigations reveal anaemia, hemoglobinuria and hemoglobinemia. He gives a history of having received primaquine chemoprophylaxis for Plasmodium vivax malaria on redeploying to a non-malarious area. Which is the most severe variant of G6PD deficiency?

A medicine internee discusses the various cell types at a clinicopathological conference in the embryology department. He demonstrates the ability of the stem cells to cross the barrier of differentiation to transform into the cell of another lineage. This cell expresses the molecular characteristics of different cell types with the capacity to perform the function of the new cell type. What is this new cell type called?

A 17-year-old girl comes to the hospital with chest pain and respiratory distress. A prominent pansystolic heart murmur and a prominent third heart sound are heard on cardiac auscultation. The patient expires despite intense supportive measures. At autopsy, microscopic findings are as shown in a given image. The mechanism of developing a given disease is which of the following?

A 45-year-old male presents with chronic diarrhea and weight loss. Investigation reveals a dysfunction in the mechanism of intestinal sugar absorption mediated by the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump. Which of the following sugars require Sodium for absorption?

A 9-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrics OPD with complaints of irritability, poor feeding, and vomiting. His mother also added that his urine smells like burnt sugar. After a proper physical examination, his urine sample is sent to the laboratory for analysis. Which of the following amino acids will not be found in this patient’s urine test?
Which of the following receptors is defective in Renal glycosuria?

A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician by the mother for abdominal distention and leg pain. Physical examination discloses developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly . Further, fundoscopic examination reveals the presence of cherry-red spots in the macula. Histological examination of the bone marrow shows foamy macrophages. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 14-month-old boy is brought to the pediatric outpatient clinic by his parents with the complaint of failure to thrive, and the baby has been passing bulky, foul-smelling stool for the last 3 weeks. The baby was diagnosed with cystic fibrosis at 3 months of age. His mother says that her sister's daughter, who is 3 months younger, has more height and weight than her baby boy. Doctor suspects deficiency of a compound with molecular formula C 17 H 31 COOH due to fat malabsorption secondary to cystic fibrosis. The molecular formula mentioned is of which of the following compound?
Omega-3 fatty acids are found in “oily” fish and are considered beneficial for heart health. A food containing which one of the following would not fall into this category?
Which of the following is a true statement regarding lipoprotein lipase?

options.label: C
options.text: Anchored to the endothelium by positively charged heparan sulfate

questions.explanation:
Location:

Extracellular attached to the luminal surface of the capillary endothelium

Acts on:

Triacylglycerols present in Chylomicron and VLDL

Activator:

Insulin

questions.text: The oxidation of glucose by the HMP pathway produces which of the following as final products?

A patient presented to casualty with nausea and vomiting. Intravenous glucose was given & the patient recover ed. After a few months, the patient presented with the same complaints, along with increased blood glutamine and elevated uracil levels . What is the most likely diagnosis ?
Which of the following is the major source of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis?

A seminar is being conducted by the department of physiology on membrane channels. It is described that hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channels are encoded by four genes (HCN1,2,3,4), with HCN4 being widely expressed in the SA node. It has also been dubbed an "f" channel, and the current is produced as a funny current. Which of the following is a function of these channels?

A professor explains the different types of transport across cell membranes and different types of transporters. ATP-binding cassette (ABC) acts as pumps, channels, or regulators and is responsible for the ATP-powered translocation of many substrates across membranes. Which of the following is the example of an ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter?
questions.correct_answer: C. SUR (Sulfonylurea receptor) in the pancreas

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presented with diarrhea for the last 3 days while on vacation. On examination, she looked dehydrated, and her capillary fill was 3 seconds. Her vital signs are normal. On the chest, auscultations are S1 and S2 heart sounds and normal respiratory sounds. The following findings are given: Hemoglobin 14 WBCs 12,000/mm3 ALT 52 U/L AST 39 U/L PH 7.28 Pco2 23 mm hg Bicarbonate 11 mEq/L Serum electrolytes Potassium = 3.1 mEq/L Sodium = 132 mEq/L Chloride= 110 mEq/L Which of the following is the correct diagnosis for this patient??

Your professor is giving a lecture on Charcot Marie Tooth Disease. He conducts a pre-test before the start of the lecture. One of the questions mentioned in the paper is, "Which among the following defective connexin causes the disease?" Choose the right answer among the following option.
Which of the following is the correct pairing of its nuclei and respective function?

options.label: A
options.text: Satiety center: lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus

options.label: B
options.text: Reward center: Ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus

options.label: C
options.text: Circadian rhythm: preoptic nuclei of the hypothalamus

options.label: D
options.text: Oxytocin secretion: paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus

questions.correct_answer: D. Oxytocin secretion: paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus
questions.explanation:
Function Hypothalamic Nuclei

Satiety center

 Ventromedial nuclei (VMN)
Reward center Medial forebrain bundle
Circadian rhythm Suprachiasmatic nucleus
Oxytocin Paraventricular nucleus
Circadian rhythm Suprachiasmatic nucleus
Temperature regulation Preoptic nucleus
Rage regulation Dorsomedial nucleus
Anterior pituitary hormone release Arcuate nucleus

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the cardiology clinic for a routine wellness visit. ECG shows no P wave but has a normal QRS complex and a normal T wave. With this given information, which is the most probable location of the pacemaker in this patient?

A 71-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypertension presents to the emergency with severe chest pain for the last 2 hours. ECG is performed. What will be his heart rate according to his lead II recording?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - 7

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents in the emergency with prolonged bleeding during a dental procedure 3 hours ago. She has been unable to control bleeding since then. On inquiring further, she says that she suffered from frequent nosebleeds and profuse bleeding from minor cuts during her childhood. She has a history of heavy menstrual flow as well. The laboratory tests show increased bleeding time and abnormal ristocetin cofactor assay. The coagulation profile reveals an increased PTT but a normal PT. Which of the following is not responsible for synthesizing the factor deficient in the etiology of this patient’s presentation?

A professor explains the glomerular filtration rate in a physiology class. GFR is the amount of plasma ultrafiltrate formed each minute and can be measured by measuring the plasma level of a substance and the amount of th e substance that is excreted. A substance to be used to measure GFR must be freely filtered through the glomeruli and must be neither secreted nor reabsorbed by the tubules. Which change tends to increase GFR?
questions.correct_answer: C. Increased glomerular capillary filtration coefficient

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and diarrhea for 1 week. She was on a trip to rural areas 10 days ago. However, she had no such symptoms while her stay in the village. Based on her laboratory results, the physician suspects metabolic acidosis. Her lungs and kidneys are functioning normally. All of the following findings are associated with this patient’s condition except?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased renal excretion of NH 4 Cl

questions.text: In which of these locations is the sodium-iodide symporter not present?
Which of the following is a true statement about gastric secretion ?

options.label: A
options.text: Gastric phase accounts for 80% of gastric secretion

options.label: B
options.text: Enterochromaffin-like cells in gastric mucosa secrete somatostatin

options.label: C
options.text: Trefoil peptides prevent erosion of gastric mucosa by gastric acid

options.label: D
options.text: Daily gastric secretion is approximately 1.0 L

questions.correct_answer: C. Trefoil peptides prevent erosion of gastric mucosa by gastric acid

questions.text: A research group wants to assess a new drug's safety and toxicity profile. A clinical trial is conducted with 20 healthy volunteers to estimate the maximum tolerated dose and monitor the apparent toxicity of the drug. The study design is best described as which of the following clinical trial phases?
Which of the following statements best describes phase IV clinical trials?

options.label: A
options.text: It is done for pediatric drugs

options.label: B
options.text: It is done for rare drugs

options.label: C
options.text: It is post-marketing surveillance of drugs

options.label: D
options.text: It is also called human pharmacology and safety studies

questions.correct_answer: C. It is post-marketing surveillance of drugs
questions.explanation:
Phase

Name

Purpose

I

Human Pharmacology and safety

To know the Maximum tolerable dose > Dose > Pharmacokinetics > Safety

II

Therapeutic Exploratory

To establish therapeutic efficacy, dose-ranging and ceiling effect

III

Therapeutic Confirmatory

To Confirm therapeutic efficacy and establish the drug's value in relation to existing therapy.

IV

Post-Marketing Surveillance

To know rare and long-term adverse effects. Special populations like pregnancy and children can be tested

0 (ZERO)

Micro-dosing studies

Knowing pharmacokinetics Could avoid the costly phase I studies for drugs with unsuitable pharmacokinetics.

questions.text: A 37-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of eye pain, nausea, and headache associated with blurred vision with coloured halos for 4 days. The general physical examination was unremarkable. On ocular exam, there is a hazy cornea, the pupils are non-reactive , and the angle of the anterior chamber is completely closed. Which of the following medication should be given to this patient?

A 56-year-old patient, who has diabetes & hypertension presents to the eye clinic with decreased visual acuity, changes in color perception, and difficulty reading associated with nausea and headache for 4 days. On the fundoscopy, macular thickening with hard exudates is seen . On ocular examination, non-reactive mid-dilated pupils with hazy cornea are noted. Which of the following drugs might be given to this patient?

A 25-year-old male comes in with complaints of episodic, intense joint pain in her left big toe for the past 4 months. On examination, you notice an erythematous swelling, which is tender on palpation. You make a diagnosis of Chronic Gout. Which of the following anti-gout drugs would you prescribe, given that it acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase ?
questions.explanation:
Group Mechanism Drugs
Uric acid synthesis inhibitors Xanthine oxidase inhibitors Allopurinol, Febuxostat
Uricosuric agents URAT-1 transporter inhibitors Probenecid, Sulfinpyrazone, Benzbromarone, Lesinurad
Recombinant uricase Cause oxidation of urate to allantoin Rasburicase, Pegloticase

questions.text: What items are essential to have on hand in an emergency situation when administering opioids to a patient?

A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by her friend after an overdose of the drug ‘x’. The patient’s friend talks about his habit of excessive drinking. His AST and ALT values are abnormally high. On seeing the empty blister packs of the tablet, the resident on duty instructs the nurse to give N-acetyl-cysteine as an antidote. Which of the following is drug x?

questions.text: A 41-year-old female presents to the outdoor patient department with complaints of increased frequency of urination and increased thirst. Her BSR chart shows that her postprandial glucose levels are in the range of 400-500 mg/dL. The doctor prescribes her a drug to take during the first part of the meal. Which of the following drugs is taken during the first part of the meal for the purpose of delaying the absorption of dietary carbohydrates?

A 55-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia for 15 years is admitted to the psychiatry ward with difficulty walking, eye spasms/blinking, protruding tongue, extended neck, agitation, hand tremors, difficulty speaking and repetitive facial movements ongoing for about four weeks and worsening gradually. Her husband mentions that she has been using some medications prescribed by her primary physician. Which of the following drugs are likely to cause these symptoms in the patient?

A 35-year-old male was brought into the emergency department after he was found to have fits. After taking a clear history, it is evident that it was a focal seizure and he had only one prior seizure episode. Liver function tests and renal function tests turned out to be normal. Which of the following drugs is the drug of choice for such seizures?

A 29-year-old male with a history of schizophrenia and allergies to second-generation antipsychotics presents to the psychiatry clinic with complaints of restlessness, tremors and insomnia following a two-week treatment with haloperidol. options.label: A
options.text: Primary gains involve external benefits and advantages.

options.label: B
options.text: Primary gains are achieved by keeping internal conflicts outside of awareness.

options.label: C
options.text: Primary gains are gains derived from personal achievements and accomplishments.

options.label: D
options.text: Primary gains reduce conscious conflicts by producing external symptoms.

questions.correct_answer: B. Primary gains are achieved by keeping internal conflicts outside of awareness.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B: Secondary gains are achieved by keeping internal conflicts outside of awareness.

Gains

Explanation

Primary Gains

Internal benefits achieved by keeping internal conflicts outside of awareness. These gains involve producing symptoms that reduce anxiety and resolve unconscious conflicts.

Secondary Gains

External benefits or advantages obtained as a result of being sick. Examples include being excused from responsibilities, receiving support from others, and being relieved from duties.

Tertiary Gains

Gains derived from significant others or family members because of the patient's symptoms. Examples include financial support, allowances, or the family members being granted relief from their own obligations to take care of the patient.

Admission is voluntary when the person wishes to get admitted and has the capacity to make mental health care or treatment decisions.

Admission of a Minor

Admission process for a minor who requires mental health care or treatment.

Supported Admission

Admission for a person who poses a threat of bodily harm to themselves or others, is unable to care for themselves, or loses capacity for decision-making. Nominated representative can provide consent for admission.

Admission of Person with High Support Needs (beyond 30 days)

Admission and treatment of a person with mental illness who requires high support, beyond the initial 30-day period.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient complains of progressive peripheral vision loss. Upon examination, optic disc pallor and attenuation of blood vessels are observed. Which layer of the retina is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: Ganglion

Layer

Description

Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE)

Outermost layer of the retina that lies adjacent to the choroid. It contains pigmented cells that absorb light and provide nourishment to the photoreceptor cells.

Photoreceptor Layer

Layer of cells that contains two types of photoreceptor cells: rods and cones. Rods are responsible for vision in low-light conditions, while cones are responsible for color vision and high visual acuity.

Outer Nuclear Layer

Layer that contains the cell bodies of the photoreceptor cells. The nuclei of rods and cones are located in this layer.

Outer Plexiform Layer

Layer where the synaptic connections between the photoreceptor cells and other retinal cells occur. It contains synaptic connections between photoreceptor cells and bipolar cells.

Inner Nuclear Layer

Layer that contains the cell bodies of the bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and horizontal cells. Bipolar cells transmit signals from the photoreceptor cells to the ganglion cells. Amacrine and horizontal cells modulate and integrate visual signals.

Inner Plexiform Layer

Layer where the synaptic connections between bipolar cells, ganglion cells, and amacrine cells occur. It contains synaptic connections between bipolar cells and ganglion cells.

Ganglion Cell Layer

Layer that contains the cell bodies of the ganglion cells. Ganglion cells receive signals from bipolar cells and transmit visual information to the brain via the optic nerve.

Nerve Fiber Layer

Layer composed of the axons of ganglion cells. These axons converge to form the optic nerve, which carries visual information to the brain.

Treatment Options for Lumbar Lordosis

Description

Physical Therapy

Involves exercises and stretches to strengthen the core muscles, improve posture, and correct muscle imbalances.

Pain Management

Includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), analgesics, and muscle relaxants to alleviate pain.

Posture Correction

Focuses on improving sitting and standing posture through ergonomic adjustments and conscious body positioning.

Weight Management

Maintaining a healthy weight reduces stress on the spine and can help alleviate symptoms associated with lordosis.

Bracing

In severe cases, a brace or orthotic device may be used to provide support and help align the spine properly.

Surgical Intervention

Reserved for severe and debilitating cases where conservative measures fail to provide relief.

Lifestyle Modifications

Incorporating regular exercise, maintaining proper nutrition, and avoiding prolonged periods of sitting or standing in one position.

Education and Body Mechanics Instruction

Learning proper body mechanics and techniques for lifting, bending, and carrying objects to avoid strain on the back.

Pain Management Techniques (e.g., heat or cold therapy)

Application of heat or cold packs to alleviate pain and reduce inflammation.

questions.text: A 52-year old lady presented with a 5-day history of jaundice and abdominal pain nausea and dark urine. She was nauseated and had dark urine. On initial assessment, she was deeply icteric , and her temperature was 38.2°C, but she was hemodynamically stable . Systemic examination did not reveal any other abnormalities. No organs or lymph nodes were palpable, and the abdomen was soft and non-tender. Biochemical analyses demonstrated leukocytosis. Intrahepatic duct dilatation was also noted. What is the best next step in treatment for this condition?

options.text: Conservative management with stone removal via ERCP

options.label: B
options.text: Adequate hydration and IV antibiotics and then elective cholecystectomy

questions.correct_answer: B. Adequate hydration and IV antibiotics and then elective cholecystectomy
questions.explanation:
CHOLANGITIS
  • Acute cholangitis is due to an acute, ascending bacterial infection of the biliary tree caused by an obstruction.
  • The classic presentation of cholangitis is Charcot triad with fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain.
  • Reynolds pentad is Charcot triad + Shock +  Altered mental status (features of shock)
  • Stones are the most common cause of obstruction in cholangitis.
  • The most common pathogens include Klebsiella, E.coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species

Diagnosis:

  • Leukocytosis with an abnormal liver panel is common.
  • Ultrasound should be the first screening test and will commonly show dilation of the biliary tree.
  • ERCP is critical not only to identify and localize the obstruction but also to drain the biliary tree and obtain culture and biopsy specimens of a lesion if necessary

Treatment:

  • Adequate hydration and IV antibiotics
  • Urgent stone removal by ERCP if the patient does not respond to medical therapy and will progress to shock
  • Patients who have suffered an episode of acute cholangitis related to gallstone disease should be recommended to undergo elective cholecystectomy approximately 6 weeks after the resolution of cholangitis

questions.text: A 19-year-old football player suddenly collapses during the game. He endured no preceding trauma. Immediate resuscitation is initiated, but he passes away before the ambulance arrives. The patient has no chronic medical conditions but complained of occasional exertion-related chest discomfort and dyspnea. A review of family history showed an uncle who died at 40 due to sudden cardiac death. Which of the following gives the pathophysiological mechanism for the patient’s sudden cardiac death?
questions.explanation:
Name Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia (ARVD)
Definition ARVD is a rare inherited cardiac disorder characterized by the progressive replacement of the right ventricular myocardium with fibrous and fatty tissue. This can lead to arrhythmias and an increased risk of sudden cardiac death.
Epidemiology ARVD is relatively rare, with a prevalence estimated at 1 in 5,000 individuals. It is more common in certain regions and populations.
Genetics Most cases of ARVD are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner and are associated with mutations in genes such as PKP2, DSP, DSG2, and others.
Clinical Features - Palpitations. - Syncope (fainting). - Ventricular arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation. - Right-sided heart failure symptoms (e.g., edema, hepatomegaly) in advanced cases.
Diagnosis - Clinical evaluation based on symptoms, family history, and electrocardiography (ECG). - Imaging studies, such as echocardiography, cardiac MRI, and right ventricular angiography, to assess structural and functional changes. - Genetic testing for mutation detection.
Electrocardiogram (ECG) ECG findings may include T-wave inversion in the right precordial leads (V1-V3), epsilon waves, and ventricular arrhythmias.
Treatment - Management aims to control arrhythmias and prevent sudden cardiac death. - Medications (e.g., beta-blockers, antiarrhythmics). - Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placement for high-risk individuals. - Lifestyle modifications and avoidance of strenuous exercise. - Genetic counseling and family screening.
Prognosis The prognosis varies but can be relatively good with appropriate management. Early diagnosis and risk stratification are crucial.
Complications - Sudden cardiac death is a significant risk, especially in untreated or high-risk individuals. - Progression to right-sided heart failure in advanced cases.

questions.explanation:
Menstrual Cycle Phase Duration Hormonal Changes Events
Menstrual Phase 3-7 days Low estrogen and progesterone Shedding of the endometrial lining; menstrual bleeding occurs
Follicular Phase 7-21 days Increasing estrogen levels Follicles in the ovaries mature, preparing to release an egg
    Low progesterone levels Uterine lining begins to thicken
Ovulation 1-2 days Surge in luteinizing hormone (LH) and estrogen Release of a mature egg (ovum) from the ovary
Luteal Phase 10-16 days Increased progesterone levels The uterine lining continues to thicken, preparing for potential embryo implantation
    Elevated estrogen levels If pregnancy does not occur, hormones begin to decline
Premenstrual Phase 2-10 days Declining estrogen and progesterone PMS symptoms may occur, and the endometrial lining is shed if fertilization did not happen

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination her vitals are normal, and systemic examination is normal however she has a blind vaginal pouch. questions.explanation:
MRKH Androgen insensitivity syndrome
Genotype XX XY
Gonad Ovaries Testes
Breast development Normal Normal
Pubic and axillary hair Normal Absent (insensitivity to testosterone)
Vagina Shallow and blind Shallow and blind
Uterus Absent Absent
Vulva Normal Normal
Sr Androgen levels 20-80 ng/dl 200-800 ng/dl

Cause of Primary Amenorrhea Description
Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) Genetic condition where an individual with XY chromosomes (genetically male) has partial or complete insensitivity to androgens.
Turner Syndrome A chromosomal disorder in females, where one of the X chromosomes is missing or structurally abnormal, leading to ovarian dysfunction.
Mullerian Agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser Syndrome) Congenital absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and upper part of the vagina, with normal ovaries and secondary sexual characteristics.
Hypothalamic or Pituitary Disorders Dysfunction or abnormalities in the hypothalamus or pituitary gland, leading to insufficient production of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) or gonadotropins (FSH and LH).
Ovarian Disorders Problems with ovarian development or function, such as ovarian dysgenesis, premature ovarian failure, or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
Anatomical Abnormalities Structural issues in the reproductive organs, such as imperforate hymen, vaginal septum, or cervical or vaginal agenesis.
Chronic Illness or Malnutrition Severe or prolonged illness, excessive physical training, or eating disorders that can disrupt hormonal regulation and menstrual cycles.
Genetic or Chromosomal Abnormalities Rare genetic syndromes or chromosomal abnormalities that affect reproductive development, such as androgen excess disorders or Kallmann syndrome.
Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) An inherited enzyme deficiency that affects cortisol and aldosterone production, leading to abnormal hormonal balance and disrupted menstrual cycles.

Emergency thoracotomy can be defined as thoracotomy "occurring either immediately at the site of injury, or in the emergency department or operating room as an integral part of the initial resuscitation process". questions.explanation:
Indications of Thoracotomy
  • Initial tube thoracostomy drainage of > 1000 ml (penetrating injury) or >1500 ml (blunt injury)
  • Ongoing tube thoracostomy drainage of >200 ml/hr for 3 consecutive hours in non-caogulopathic patients
  • Caked hemothorax despite of placement of two chest tubes Tracheo-bronchial injury
  • Selected descending torn aorta or great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac herniation
  • Massive air leak from chest tube with inadequate ventilation
  • Open pneumothorax Esophageal perforation
